awd_titl_txt: Density Functional Theory of Electronic Structure
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY
The Division of Materials Research and the Chemistry Division contribute funds to this award that will lead to more accurate computer modeling of molecules, chemicals, and materials. To do this the PI will focus on the "glue" that binds one atom to another to form molecules and materials which has the technical name exchange-correlation energy. Making this energy smaller strengthens the "glue" because electrons avoid close approaches to other electrons which have the same electric charge. The density of electrons determines the exchange-correlation energy, but the exact formula is not known. Nevertheless, it is possible to use a computer to predict what molecules and materials can exist, and with what properties, by using an approximate formula. The PI has developed approximate formulas that lead to good predictions of the properties of many materials and molecules as compared with actual experiments. In this research the PI will develop even more accurate approximations for the "glue" that still lend themselves to efficient simulation of molecules, and materials on a computer. 
The PI's most recent approximate formula is called SCAN. As a feature, it shares all the attributes of the exact formula that are known from fundamental principles of quantum mechanics that are possible for an approximation like SCAN. Nevertheless, no formula of this type can be exact; approximations of this type introduce a spurious interaction of an electron with itself. A major goal of this project will be to develop a widely-useful correction to overcome this source of error for SCAN.
The development of more accurate approximations for the "glue" that holds atoms together leads to better predictions for the properties of chemicals, molecules, and materials. These predictions can lead to the discovery of new materials with desired properties for a wide range of applications from building and construction, to sophisticated electronic devices, to biomaterials for medical applications, and more. This research enables better computer modeling of materials with potential impact on the Materials Genome Initiative. This award also helps support the PI's efforts to develop better ways to help educate more high-school physics teachers,and to involve undergraduate students in the research.

TECHNICAL SUMMARY
 The Division of Materials Research and the Chemistry Division contribute funds to this award that supports research in Kohn-Sham density functional theory, the most widely-used method to calculate ground-state energies or energy differences, equilibrium nuclear positions, and electron densities in atoms, molecules, and solids. The theory is exact in principle, although in practice the density functional for the exchange-correlation energy must be approximated. In the preceding award period, the Perdew research group developed SCAN, a "strongly constrained and appropriately normed" functional that is more accurate for diversely-bonded systems than comparably-efficient approximations. Satisfying all 17 known exact constraints that a semilocal functional can, the SCAN meta-generalized gradient approximation could replace the widely-used Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof generalized gradient approximation.

In the current award period, extensive tests will be made for SCAN and for SCAN with a long-range van der Waals correction. These tests would include the formation energies which determine relative stabilities of molecules and solids from the elements in their standard states, large reference-data sets for sp-bonded and transition-element-containing molecules, the polyacetylene chain, the ground-state crystal structures of solids that have proven challenging to get correct for , fundamental band gaps of solids, surface energies and work functions of metals, and adsorption energies for molecules on surfaces, A refined self-interaction correction to SCAN would seek to preserve the excellent SCAN description of equilibrium bonds for weakly-correlated systems while improving the description of stretched bonds, charge transfers, and  strongly-correlated systems. A SCAN-like additive correction to the fully-nonlocal random phase approximation would be developed. Proof would be sought for a hypothesized tight lower bound on the exchange energy of any spin-unpolarized density. Finally, exchange-correlation energy differences for selected systems would be analyzed in a way that could lead to a better understanding of electronic systems and their properties, and of the successes of SCAN. The development of more accurate approximations for exchange-correlation functions will result in better predictions for the properties of atoms, molecules, and materials and can lead to the discovery of new materials with desired properties for a wide range of applications from building and construction to sophisticated electronic devices to biomaterials for medical applications and more. This research enables better computer modeling of materials with potential impact on the Materials Genome Initiative. This award also helps support the PI's efforts to develop better ways to help educate more high-school physics teachers, and to involve undergraduate students in the research.

por.por_cntn:
Kohn-Sham density functional theory (DFT) is a formally exact way to calculate the ground-state energy and electron density of a system of interacting electrons by solving self-consistent one-electron Schroedinger equations. In practice, only the exchange-correlation energy as a functional of the electron density needs to be approximated. Existing approximations that are usefully accurate and computationally efficient have made DFT the most widely-used method to predict on the computer what atoms, molecules, solids, and liquids can exist, with what structures and properties. But more accurate approximations are needed to make more reliable computer predictions for the discovery of new molecules and materials. Sometimes small quantitative errors imply large qualitative ones, as in the prediction of the ground-state crystal structure for a given element or compound.

The goal of this project has been to develop improved approximations that will reliably deliver "the right answer for the right reason at the right price". The right answer implies greater accuracy over a wider range of materials and properties, including those unlike any computed before. The right reason implies that the approximation is grounded in the principles of quantum mechanics, and not fitted to any bonded system. The right price implies that the cost is not much greater than it is for the existing local spin density approximation (LSDA), generalized gradient approximation (GGA), or meta-GGA.

The SCAN density functional was constructed in this research group to satisfy all 17 exact constraints that a meta-GGA can satisfy. The predictions that it makes for bonded molecules and materials are pure predictions, and not fits. Tests made in this grant period show that SCAN accurately describes the surfaces of transition metals, the critical pressures for structural phase transitions in semi-conductors, and the formation energies and lowest-energy crystal structures of strongly -bonded solids. SCAN has also been successful where no density functional approximation was expected to be: in ?complex? systems like the hydrogen-bonded networks of molecules in liquid water or ice, and in some ?strongly-correlated? systems like the cuprate high-temperature superconducting materials.

Standard density functional approximations including SCAN make self-interaction errors: they are not exact in the simple one-electron limit. The 1981 Perdew-Zunger self-interaction correction (PZ SIC) makes any approximate functional exact for all one-electron densities. In the current grant period, a way was found to find self-consistent occupied orbitals for PZ SIC in the size-consistent Fermi-Loewdin formalism. As known before, PZ SIC  results are mixed, with a better description of stretched bonds but an often-worsened description of equilibrium bonds. In the current grant period, the explanation for this was found: PZ SIC loses the exact uniform-density limit that is built into almost every approximate functional. The solution is then to keep the full PZ SIC in one-electron regions, and to scale it down to zero in uniform-density regions. This works well as a correction to the simple local spin-density approximation (LDA), for which the energy densities of the self-Hartree and self-exchange-correlation terms of the PZ SIC are in the same gauge, but it only works for GGA?s and meta-GGA?s after a gauge transformation is made to consistent gauges.  A reliable self-interaction correction to good functional like SCAN might open the door to a good DFT description of the ground-state properties of most ?strongly correlated? materials.

"Density-driven" self-interaction errors were found to explain the long-standing "carbon monoxide adsorption puzzle".

Water in its condensed phases is well-described by SCAN, with accurate small energy differences between different structures, but SCAN still strongly overestimates the energy needed to break (and not just to rearrange) the hydrogen bonds between water molecules. PZ SIC applied to SCAN corrects most of this overbinding, without losing SCAN?s accurate structural energy differences. That work shows the promise of self-interaction correction for a material of great importance to chemistry and to life.

In this grant period, the classical turning surface of the Kohn-Sham potential of DFT was shown to provide an ideal visualization of the sizes, shapes, and bonding properties of molecules. It was also found that density functionals heavily fitted to molecular energy differences are less accurate for the densities of atoms than functionals with few or no such fitted parameters. It was also found that analytic expressions for the correlation energy per electron of a uniform electron gas as a function of density, that are constrained to known high-density limits, are actually more accurate than recent quantum Monte Carlo values which suffer from fixed-node error in that limit.

24 journal articles and 26 invited talks at cnferences were supported by this grant. Two graduate research assistants received Ph.D.'s and are now postdoctoral fellows in other universities. Three undergraduates and a high-school student paricipated in the research. The PI gave an annual tutorial on DFT at the American Physical Society March meeting, and a talk at an APS Conference for Undergraduate Women in Physics.
